raw_text:
Oil companies get Russian setback
 
 International oil and mining companies have reacted cautiously to Russia's decision to bar foreign firms from natural resource tenders in 2005.
 
 US oil giant Exxon said it did not plan to take part in a new tender on a project for which it had previously signed a preliminary agreement. Miner Highland Gold said it regretted any limit on privatisation while BP, a big investor, declined to comment. Only firms at least 51% Russian-owned will be permitted to bid.
 
 The Federal Natural Resources Agency said "the government is interested in letting Russian companies develop strategic resources". The foreign ownership issue will be dealt with according to Russia's competition law, natural resources minister Yuri Trutnev was quoted as saying by the Interfax news agency. No further details were given, with Mr Trutnev suggesting that Russia may decide on a case-by-case basis. Observers said that the move may represent a shift in policy, as the administration of Vladimir Putin puts the protection of national interests above free market dynamics. Russia recently wrested back control of a large chunk of its oil industry from stock-market listed company Yukos, a move that prompted calls of outrage from many investors.
 
 Analysts warned that it was still too early to draw too many conclusions from this new set of proposals.
 
 Companies echoed this sentiment, saying that they would require more information before ringing the alarm bells. "It's not good. But it is very understandable," said Al Breach, an economist at UBS Brunswick. "But if the investment climate is stable - that's much more important. "Foreigners of course would like to have free entry but... this is not the end of the world." A number of other nations, including Mexico, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, protect their national resources from foreign firms. What has surprised observers is that since the collapse of communism Russia has been courting foreign investment.
 
 BP spent $7.5bn to create Russian-registered oil company TNK-BP, and has a partnership to develop the Sakhalin 5 petroleum field with state-owned Rosneft. Exxon, the world's largest oil company, has signed preliminary agreements to develop the Sakhalin 3 field. Company spokesman Glenn Waller said Exxon still considered the deal valid, despite Russia inviting new offers for the land block. According to Mr Waller, Exxon "were not planning to bid at a new tender anyway". "We regret the ministry has taken such a decision," said Ivan Kulakov, deputy chairman of Highland Gold - a mining firm that has the motto "Bringing Russia's Gold to Market". "It would be a shame if that has a negative impact on the investment climate." Other firms that have been linked with investment in Russia include France's Total, the US-based ChevronTexaco, and miner Barrick Gold.
llama3.2:1b: International oil and mining companies are reacting cautiously to Russia's decision to limit foreign participation in natural resource tenders in 2005 due to concerns about protecting national interests. Exxon does not plan to bid on a new project after signing a preliminary agreement, while Highland Gold regrets the limitation on privatisation. BP has declined to comment, and Total and ChevronTexaco have also expressed similar sentiments. Russia's minister, Yuri Trutnev, suggests that the country may take a case-by-case approach when deciding whether to allow foreign firms to bid.
llama3.2:3b: Russia bars foreign firms from natural resource tenders citing national interests over free market dynamics amid a shift in policy after reclaiming Yukos oil industry control. Oil companies including Exxon, BP, Highland Gold, and others express caution, warning of potential impact on investment climate before more information is available.
gemma2:2b: International oil and mining companies are reacting cautiously to Russia's decision to limit foreign ownership in natural resource tenders, which will only allow Russian-owned companies to bid.  Some companies like Exxon and Highland Gold have expressed concern but haven't ruled out participation entirely. The move is seen as a shift in policy towards protecting national interests over free market dynamics, following recent moves by the government to regain control of the oil industry from listed companies. Experts caution that it's too early to draw conclusions, but some point to Russia's past willingness to attract foreign investment.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Oil companies are concerned about Russian decisions, specifically over foreign participation in natural resource tenders. They remain cautious and will consider further details before making any final commitments. The Federal Natural Resources Agency said they were interested in allowing Russian companies to develop strategic resources. Some observers suggest this might represent a shift in policy as the administration of Vladimir Putin prioritizes national interests above free market dynamics. Other nations, including Mexico, Saudi Arabia, and Kuwait, protect their national resources from foreign firms. Companies are also concerned that Russia is courting foreign investment despite the country's collapse under communism. Exxon has already signed preliminary agreements to develop natural gas fields in the Sakhalin region.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Oil companies have expressed cautious reactions to Russia's 2005 natural resource tender ban due to foreign ownership restrictions, which follows Yukos' takeover by stock-market listed company YUKOS earlier this year. The Federal Natural Resources Agency says the move is aimed at Russian strategic resources development and will be regulated under competition law. Analysts caution that these new proposals are premature, with many nations protecting their own national resources from foreign investment.
qwen2.5:3b: International oil and mining companies have reacted cautiously to Russia's decision to bar foreign firms from natural resource tenders since 2005. Exxon announced it would not participate in a new tender for a project where it had already signed an agreement. Highland Gold expressed regret over privatization limits, while BP declined to comment. Only at least 51% Russian-owned companies will be allowed to bid. The Federal Natural Resources Agency emphasized protecting national interests, aligning with Putin's administration’s stance. Analysts and industry leaders caution against premature conclusions, noting Russia recently reacquired control of its oil sector from Yukos. Countries like Mexico, Saudi Arabia, and Kuwait also protect their resources from foreign firms. Exxon, BP, and mining companies including Highland Gold are still considering the validity of deals and investments in Russia despite the new restrictions.

smollm:1.7b:
The summary is as follows:

Oil companies react cautiously to Russia's decision to bar foreign firms from natural resource tenders in 2005. The US oil company Exxon said it did not plan to take part in a new tender on a project for which it had previously signed a preliminary agreement, while Miner Highland Gold and BP declined to comment. Only firms at least 51% Russian-owned will be permitted to bid.

The Federal Natural Resources Agency said "the government is interested in letting Russian companies develop strategic resources". The foreign ownership issue will be dealt with according to Russia's competition law, natural resources minister Yuri Trutnev was quoted as saying by the Interfax news agency. No further details were given, with Mr Trutnev suggesting that Russia may decide on a case-by-case basis.

Russia recently wrested back control of a large chunk of its oil industry from stock-market listed company Yukos, a move that prompted calls of outrage from many investors. "It is very understandable," said Al Breach, an economist at UBS Brunswick. "But if the investment climate is stable - that's much more important." Foreigners of course would like to have free entry but... this is not the end of the world."

A number of other nations, including Mexico, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, protect their national resources from foreign firms. What has surprised observers is that since the collapse of communism Russia has been courting foreign investment.

BP spent $7.5bn to create Russian-registered oil company TNK-BP, and has a partnership to develop the Sakhalin 3 field with state-owned Rosneft. Exxon, the world's largest oil company, has signed preliminary agreements to develop the Sakhalin 2 field with Russia. Company spokesman Glenn Waller said Exxon "were not planning to bid at a new tender anyway". "We regret the ministry has taken such a decision," said Ivan Kulakov, deputy chairman of Highland Gold - a mining firm that has the motto "Bringing Russia's Gold to Market". "It would be a shame if that has a negative impact on the investment climate." Other firms that have been linked with investment in Russia include France's Total, the US-based ChevronTexaco, and miner Barrick Gold.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about oil companies reacting to Russia's decision about foreign firm participation in natural resource tenders. Let me read through it carefully.

First, the main event is that Russian companies blocked foreign firms from taking on new projects in 2005. Companies like Exxon, Miner Highland Gold, and BP have reacted by refusing to participate. The Federal Natural Resources Agency said they're interested in letting Russian companies develop their strategic resources under Russia's competition law. They don't know exactly how it'll be done but suggest a case-by-case approach.

There are some key points: only at least 51% Russian-owned firms can bid, foreigners want free entry but the move isn't about ending the free market yet. Some countries have already been investing in Russia, like Mexico and Saudi Arabia. Observers think this shift could be important because of Russia's recent control change from Yukos under a stock market list.

 Analysts warn that it's still too early to make conclusions yet. Firms are still required to get more info before they react. BP and Exxon signed projects with Russian companies, but their deals seem valid even after Russia invited new offers.

I should focus on the main reactions of major oil companies, the impact of the natural resources agency decision, the shift in foreign investment countries, and the warning about the timing of the move.
</think>

Oil companies have faced cautious responses from Russia regarding foreign participation in their projects. Exxon, Miner Highland Gold, and BP declined to join new tenders for projects previously signed with Russia. The Federal Natural Resources Agency expressed interest in Russian strategic resources under Russia's competition law but suggested a case-by-case approach due to uncertainty. Only firms at least 51% Russian-owned can bid. Foreign companies desire free entry but the move isn't about ending free market dynamics. Observers note a shift in investment policies, with countries like Mexico and Saudi Arabia already supporting Russian investments, while some have requested Russia's involvement. Analysts warn that conclusions on Russia's decision won't be drawn until more information is provided. Despite this, companies are expected to act based on the information available.
tinyllama:1.1b: Ahead of a new round of natural resource tender bids in Russia, oil companies have taken notice of the country's decision to limit foreign firm participation in order to maintain national interests. Despite this move, some firms have expressed concern and caution regarding its potential impact on investment opportunities in Russia. The recent announcement that companies would need more information before calling for alarm bells has been interpreted as a sign of growing unease about the new policy. However, observers have noted that Russia's decision to protect national resources is not necessarily the end of the world and are unsure what to make of the collateral damage to foreign investment. Despite the uncertainty, some firms still consider investing in Russia despite the government's move to limit foreign participation in natural resource tender bids.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The international oil and mining companies are reacting cautiously to Russia's decision to bar foreign firms from participating in natural resource tenders in 2005. Despite this setback for Western investors, Exxon is not planning to take part in the new tender, while other companies like Highland Gold are regretting any limit on their participation. BP has reached a preliminary agreement with Rosneft to develop Sakhalin 3, but it remains unclear whether this deal will hold up given Russia's stance on foreign ownership restrictions. Exxon and ChevronTexaco continue to be linked with investment in Russia, particularly in the oil sector.
phi:2.7b: Oil companies reacted cautiously to Russia's decision to ban foreign firms from natural resource tenders. Only Russian companies at least 51% owned can bid on projects. This move may represent a shift in policy, as Russia prioritizes national interests over free market dynamics. Foreign investors have expressed concern about this new set of proposals but emphasized the importance of a stable investment climate. While other countries protect their resources from foreign firms, Russia has been courting foreign investment since the collapse of communism. BP and Exxon have signed agreements to develop oil fields in Russia despite the ban on foreign firms. Highland Gold regretted any limit on privatization, while other companies such as ChevronTexaco and Barrick Gold were not affected by the decision.
orca-mini:3b: The text reports that Russian oil companies and mining firms have reacted cautiously to the government's decision to bar foreign firms from natural resource tenders in 2005. The move has been seen as a shift in policy for Russia's administration of Vladimir Putin, who prioritizes the protection of national interests over free market dynamics. Oil giants like Exxon and BP have shown caution in taking part in new tenders while Rosneft, a state-owned company, has also been involved in foreign partnerships. The Federal Natural Resources Agency has expressed interest in letting Russian companies develop strategic resources, while the government may decide on a case-by-case basis to allow foreign firms to participate. Analysts warn that it is still too early to draw conclusions from this new set of proposals.
hermes3:3b: Oil companies react to Russian ban on foreign firms participating in natural resource tenders, as Exxon, BP, Highland Gold etc. regrettably accept restriction.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Russia decided to only allow foreign companies that own at least 51% Russian shares to participate in natural resource tenders starting in 2005. This was met with cautious reactions from international oil and mining firms. Exxon did not plan to take part in the tender, while Highland Gold expressed regret over the limit on privatization. The issue of foreign ownership would be dealt with according to Russia's competition law. Analysts warned it was too early to draw conclusions, but some nations had previously protected their resources from foreign companies. This move surprised observers given that post-communist Russia had been courting foreign investment.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Russia has decided to bar foreign firms from bidding on natural resource tenders in 2005, allowing only companies that are at least 51% Russian-owned. This move has prompted cautious reactions from international oil and mining companies, with Exxon opting out of a new tender and Highland Gold expressing regret over the restriction. The government stated that Russian firms should develop strategic resources, and foreign ownership will be handled under competition law. Analysts suggest this may signal a shift in policy under President Putin, prioritizing national interests over free market principles, as seen in the state's recent reclaiming of Yukos assets. While some investors are concerned, others note that similar restrictions exist in countries like Mexico and Saudi Arabia. BP, which has invested heavily in Russia, and Exxon, which has agreements for the Sakhalin 3 field, are monitoring the situation. Observers remain uncertain about the long-term impact on Russia’s investment climate.
stablelm2:1.6b:
Russia bars foreign firms from natural resource tenders due to a 50% minimum Russian ownership requirement. This decision has been cautiously received by international oil companies like Exxon, while others such.
 
As mentioned in the text, this is a response to Russia's decision and not the cause of it. The text highlights that many international oil and mining companies are reacting cautiously to this move. 

The key ideas and details which can be preserved for the summary are:

1. Oil companies have reacted cautiously to Russia’s decision.
2. Russian government is interested in allowing Russian companies to develop strategic resources.
3. Foreign ownership issue will be dealt with according to Russia's competition law.
4. Only firms at least 50% Russian-ownable will be permitted to bid.
5. Exxon said it did not plan to take part in the tender.
6. BP, a big investor, declined to comment on the situation.

The summary would read: "Russia bars foreign firms from natural resource tenders due to 50% minimum Russian ownership requirement; international oil companies react cautiously." 

This summary includes all of the key details from the original text without going into any additional information.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Russian authorities have restricted foreign oil and mining companies from participating in national resource tenders due to a 2005 decree, impacting major players like Exxon, Highland Gold, BP, Total, ChevronTexaco, and Barrick Gold. Only majority Russian-owned firms can bid, citing the government's preference for domestic development of strategic resources. This move is seen as a potential shift in policy by some observers, given Russia's recent seizure of Yukos' assets. While companies acknowledge the setback and regret the decision, they express understanding and emphasize the importance of a stable investment climate. Analysts caution against premature judgments, noting that further information is needed to assess the full implications. Notably, Russia has historically courted foreign investment since the fall of communism; however, several other nations maintain protectionist policies for their national resources.
reference: Exxon, the world's largest oil company, has signed preliminary agreements to develop the Sakhalin 3 field.International oil and mining companies have reacted cautiously to Russia's decision to bar foreign firms from natural resource tenders in 2005."We regret the ministry has taken such a decision," said Ivan Kulakov, deputy chairman of Highland Gold - a mining firm that has the motto "Bringing Russia's Gold to Market".Company spokesman Glenn Waller said Exxon still considered the deal valid, despite Russia inviting new offers for the land block.What has surprised observers is that since the collapse of communism Russia has been courting foreign investment."It would be a shame if that has a negative impact on the investment climate."US oil giant Exxon said it did not plan to take part in a new tender on a project for which it had previously signed a preliminary agreement.BP spent $7.5bn to create Russian-registered oil company TNK-BP, and has a partnership to develop the Sakhalin 5 petroleum field with state-owned Rosneft.Other firms that have been linked with investment in Russia include France's Total, the US-based ChevronTexaco, and miner Barrick Gold.According to Mr Waller, Exxon "were not planning to bid at a new tender anyway".
